questions.text: An adult patient complains of palpitations and presents with an irregularly irregular pulse. Pulse deficit is 20/hr=120/min, BP= 110/70 mm hg. Which of the following will be found in this patient?
questions.solution:
Irregularly irregular pulse, Pulse deficit> 10 indicates Atrial Fibrillation.

A wave in JVP is an expression of normal atrial contraction.

In JVP, a patient with AF 'a' wave will be absent.

questions.text: Which of the following electrolyte imbalance will produce ecg findings of st depression and u waves?
questions.solution:
Hypokalemia prolongs ventricular repolarization, often with prominent U waves. There will be QT prolongation.

Prolongation of the QT interval is also seen with drugs that increase the duration of the ventricular action potential:

  • class 1A antiarrhythmic agents and related drugs (e.g., quinidine, disopyramide, procainamide, tricyclic antidepressants, phenothiazines) and
  • class III agents (e.g., amiodarone, dofetilide, sotalol, ibutilide).
  • Systemic hypothermia also prolongs repolarization, usually with a distinctive convex elevation of the J point (Osborn wave).
  • Marked QT prolongation, sometimes with deep, wide T-wave inversions, may occur with intracranial bleeds, particularly subarachnoid hemorrhage ("CVA T-wave" pattern)

Hypocalcemia typically prolongs the QT interval (ST portion), whereas hypercalcemia shortens it.

ST elevation is caused by hyperkalemia, hypercalcemia and hypothermia.

questions.text: An 82-year-old patient with hypertension comes with acute onset of breathlessness. Chest x-ray is shown below. What should be done next?
questions.solution:
Nitroglycerin is a vasodilator commonly used to manage acute pulmonary edema secondary to hypertension. By dilating blood vessels, it reduces preload and afterload on the heart, thereby decreasing the work of the heart and improving cardiac output. This can help alleviate pulmonary congestion and edema. Therefore, IV nitroglycerin is often considered the treatment of choice for acute pulmonary edema associated with hypertension.

Other CXR findings include:

  • Upper lobe venous congestion,
  • Thickened interlobular septum,
  • Interstitial edema,
  • Kerley B lines. Once PCWP is elevated to moderate or severe levels

A. Oxygen + Antibiotics: While oxygen therapy is crucial for maintaining adequate oxygenation in patients with pulmonary edema, antibiotics are not typically indicated unless there is a concurrent infection. Antibiotics would not directly address the acute pulmonary edema associated with hypertension.

B. Intravenous Salbutamol (Albuterol): Salbutamol is a bronchodilator commonly used in conditions such as asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). While it may help alleviate some symptoms associated with pulmonary edema by reducing bronchospasm, it is not the primary treatment for acute pulmonary edema.

D. Nebulized Salbutamol (Albuterol): Nebulized salbutamol is similar to intravenous salbutamol in its mechanism of action as a bronchodilator. While it may provide some relief for respiratory symptoms, it is not the primary treatment for acute pulmonary edema.

questions.text: A 74-year-old patient with cad presents with palpitations. ECG is shown below. Bp-120/84 mm hg. Which of the following shall be the best treatment for this patient?
questions.solution: The question deals with wide complex tachycardia with a stable BP of 120/80 suggestive of stable VT. Drug is iv Amiodarone

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient with dental caries is undergoing dental extraction. Which of the following does not need prophylaxis for endocarditis?
questions.solution: Indications of IE prophylaxis:

questions.text: A patient presents with digoxin toxicity. Pulse rate is 54/min with ECG evidence of 3rd degree heart block. What is the best treatment?
questions.solution:
Digitalis is a drug with a very narrow therapeutic index.

Digitalis toxicity produces a variety of side effects including headache, nausea, vomiting, altered colour perception, halo vision and malaise.

Serious adverse events include arrhythmias, mostly bradyarrhythmias due to the enhanced vagal tone. Tachyarrhythmia can also occur.

Phenytoin is used to control atrial tachy arrhythmias and

lignocaine for ventricular tachy arrhythmias.

Brady arrhythmias respond to withdrawal of digoxin, atropine or temporary pacing.

Digoxin-specific antibody fragments for

  • hemodynamically compromising dysrhythmias,
  • Mobitz II or third degree atrioventricular block,
  • hyperkalemia (>5.5 meq/L; in acute poisoning only).

Temporizing measures include atropine, dopamine, epinephrine, and external cardiac pacing for bradydysrhythmias and magnesium, lidocaine, or phenytoin, for ventricular tachydysrhythmias.

Internal cardiac pacing and cardioversion can increase ventricular irritability and should be reserved for refractory cases.

choices.text: For 5 years 3 weekly or 21 years of age
Till 10 years 3 weekly or till 25 years of age

questions.text: An 11-year-old child with manifestations of rheumatic fever is prescribed 0.6 mu im benzathine penicillin. Which of the following is correct for secondary prevention?
questions.solution:
In the given question no details of the patient are given. Hence we assume its isolated RF without carditis. Hence answer is option C.

Secondary prophylaxis of acute rheumatic fever

  • Best drug-iv Benzathine penicillin-1.2mu every 4 weeks(3 weeks or 2 weeks if patient is at high risk)
  • Alternative - Oral penicillin V - 250 mg twice daily.

Duration of treatment Table 359-4

questions.text: A 35 year old female who was on antidepressant medications now presents with altered sensorium, hyperthermia, dilated pupils, urinary retention and hypotension. ECG shows broad complex tachycardia. What treatment has to be given to the patient?
questions.solution:
The history is suggestive of TCA poisoning and drug of choice for TCA poisoning is sodium bicarbonate.

IV sodium bicarbonate: Sodium bicarbonate may be used in the treatment of tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) overdose to counteract the cardiac toxicity by sodium channel blockade. However, its use should be considered cautiously and is typically reserved for severe cases. In this scenario, while the patient is experiencing broad complex tachycardia, sodium bicarbonate may not be the initial treatment of choice.

B. Sotalol: Sotalol is a beta-blocker that can rapidly control heart rate and blood pressure. However, in this case, where there is a broad complex tachycardia with right axis deviation, indicating a potential ventricular tachycardia, the use of a beta-blocker may exacerbate the condition and is not recommended as the initial treatment.

C. Wait and watch: Waiting and watching without intervention is not advisable in this scenario. The patient is experiencing significant symptoms and findings on ECG that require prompt medical attention and intervention.

questions.text: A young female presents with a left sided throbbing headache. She also has nausea, vomiting, aura and phonophobia. What is the best treatment for immediate relief?
questions.solution:
The question deals with treatment of an acute attack of migraine. Among the given options, only Sumartriptan is used for aborting an acute episode.

The others are used for prophylaxis of migraine.

The drugs used in acute migraine

  • Acetaminophen
  • NSAIDS
  • HTIB/ID receptor agonists - Triptans-Oral/Nasal/Parenteral
  • CGRP receptor agonists-Oral-Rimegepant, Ubrogepant
  • 5HT1F receptor agonists-Ditans-Oral-Lasmiditan No action in vasculature, Safe in cardiovascular diseases
  • Dopamine receptor agonists-Metoclopramide & domperidone Chlorpromazine, Prochlorparazine.

questions.text: CSF specimen of patient is shown below. Report shows mononuclear cytosis with moderately low sugar with elevated protein values. Which of the following is the likely etiology?
questions.solution:
• Mononuclear cells in CSF suggest lymphocytes.
  • CSF lymphocytosis is seen in TB or viral meningitis.
  • Low sugar and protein elevation rules out viral meningitis.
  • The diagram shows cloudy CSF due to high protein and AFB on microscopy.
  • CSF forms cobweb coagulum.
  • Early TBM can cause polymorphonuclear leukocytosis, but count <500
  • Risk factors - Exposure, Previous TB, Immunosuppression, anti TNF-α treatment, AIDS.

questions.text: A child born by normal vaginal delivery has repeated attacks of flexion of neck over the trunk jerks in hands. EEG shows hypsarrhythmia. What is the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
The question deals with infantile epileptic spasms.

Clinical features: Briefly sustained flexion & extension of proximal & truncal muscles

EEG: Hypsarrhythmia-diffuse, giant slow waves in a chaotic background of irregular multifocal sharp waves and spikes

During the spam the EEG background will be markedly suppressed

EMG: Rhomboid pattern

Treatment: ACTH, When present along with Tuberous Sclerosis - Vigabatrin.

questions.text: A patient who suffered from stroke previously has now presented with sudden onset flailing arm ballistic movement. Comment on site of lesion.
questions.solution:
The involuntary movement described is hemiballismus.

Lesion is in sub thalamic nucleus.30-40% lesion is in putamen, thalamus or parietal cortex.

Chorea - lesion is in the caudate nucleus.

Athetosis - Globus pallidus

Parkinson - substantia nigra

questions.text: A 4 year old child presented with progressive walking difficulty, frequent falls and difficulty in getting up from a squatting position. Serum CK is elevated. Muscle biopsy finding is shown. Choose the true statement?
questions.solution:
The history and the muscle biopsy showed suggestive of Duchene muscular dystrophy

Bad prognosis.

X linked inheritance.

Due to absence of dystrophin gene.

questions.text: 8 year old girl presents with epigastric pain & vomiting for the past 10 days. Since the last 3 days, she also has oliguria & features of dehydration. Peripheral smear shows presence of lymphoblasts. What will be the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given history in the question suggest uric acid induced nephropathy, which is due to tumour lysis syndrome.

For management of tumour syndrome, first step is adequate hydration.

questions.text: An old age smoker presents with respiratory difficulty. Abg report: ph=7.2, po2=75 mm hg, pco2 =84 mm hg, hco3-35meq. Diagnosis
questions.solution:
Here the pH is acidotic. pCO2 is 84.

For respiratory acidosis, the pCO2 is greater than 40 to 45 due to decreased ventilation.

Hence it is primary respiratory acidosis.

questions.text: Patient presents with teeth gap widening, frontal bone thickening along with foot and hand enlargement. What is the first line of treatment?
questions.solution:
Here pre op treatment with SRL is the first line, If the tumor is resectable (Not mentioned in question) Surgery is the first line.

The question deals with acromegaly.

The definitive treatment of acromegaly is surgical resection of pituitary adenoma medical treatment is only possible with somatostatin receptor analogues indicated in

  • Pre op shrinkage of tumor
  • Immediate relief of debilitating symptoms
  • Frail patients
  • Failure of surgical treatment

Medical treatment

Somatostatin receptor ligands-Ochleotide (Oral/injectable) & Acts on SST2 & SST5 receptors. Decreases both GH and IGF 1 levels.

Pasireotide LAR is a multi receptor ligand with preferential SST5 binding - achieves biochemical control in patients resistant to Octreotide and Lanreotide.

GH receptor antagonists-Pegvisomant Blocks peripheral GH receptor. IGF 1 levels are reduced. But GH levels remain increased.

  • Drug doesn't target pituitary adenoma.
  • No change in tumor size - Hence monitoring of tumor size is

questions.text: A patient presents with recurrence of pituitary tumor overproducing gh. Which is the best drug to be used?
questions.solution: Best drug to treat failed surgery is SRL

questions.text: A 26 year old female presents with amenorrhea and galactorrhea. On evaluation, MRI showed pituitary macroadenoma. Which of the following can be given for the medical management?

A female who is a known case of diabetes mellitus and noncompliant to medication is brought to ER with abdominal pain, vomiting episodes and recent onset confusion. On examination she is dehydrated with sbp 90 mm hg. Work up shows urine ketones present with rbs 598 mg%. Which of the following will be the next best step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The question deals with DKA suggested by hyperglycemia, hypotension & dehydration with positive ketone bodies in urine examination.

The initial management of DKA is iv fluids with regular insulin.

questions.text: A female patient complains of loosening of one tooth and hemi facial pain. Patient was previously treated for covid-19, 4 months ago. Which of the following tests need to be done on priority basis?
questions.solution:
Nasal swab for mucur

Mucormycosis typically begins with fungal spores entering the body through the respiratory tract, often via inhalation. In patients recovering from COVID-19, especially those who have been treated with steroids, the risk of mucormycosis increases due to the immunosuppressive effects of steroids and the damage to the respiratory mucosa caused by the virus.

The first step in diagnosing mucormycosis is obtaining a tissue or swab sample from the affected area for fungal culture and microscopy. In this case, given the recent history of COVID-19 and the symptoms of loosening of one tooth and hemifacial pain, a nasal swab for mucor should be done on a priority basis to determine if mucormycosis is present.

The other options:

A. HbA1C: This test measures average blood glucose levels over the past 2-3 months and is primarily used to diagnose and monitor diabetes. While it may be relevant in some cases, it is not the priority in this scenario.

B. Ferritin: Ferritin levels may be elevated in various conditions, including inflammatory processes and infections. However, in this case, the symptoms are more suggestive of a fungal infection, so a nasal swab for mucor would be more appropriate.

D. MRI head: While an MRI of the head may be indicated later in the diagnostic process to assess the extent of the infection, confirm tissue involvement, or evaluate for complications, obtaining a nasal swab for mucor to confirm the diagnosis should be the priority before proceeding with imaging studies.

Diagnosis of mucormycosis:

  • Biopsy with histopathological examination is the most sensitive method and should be done in all high risk patients.
  • Wide thick walled ribbon like aseptate fungal branching at right angles will be seen.
  • Artificial septae can occur during tissue processing hence the width and the ribbon like appearance are the most reliable features.

Imaging:

  • CT/MRI Indistinguishable from other causes of sinusitis.
  • MRI is more sensitive for detecting orbital and CNS disease.
  • CT will not detect bone erosion.

questions.text: Which of the following will decrease serum K+ via intracellular shift?
questions.solution: Epinephrine will act upon sodium potassium ATP channel, there is a beta receptor linked to this channel, which is responsible for hypokalemia via intracellular shift.

questions.text: A 8 year old boy presented to the emergency department with abdominal pain, palpable purpura and melena. Which of the following will be used in the treatment?
questions.solution:
The scenario explained in the question is of HSP.

  • Classical HSP presence with non-thrombocyte, non-palpable purPura, especially on the buttocks and extensor aspect of limbs.
  • Majority of the patients present with gastrointestinal symptoms like nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain.
  • Abdominal pain is often called bowel angina.
  • Other symptoms of HSP are arthritis, arthralgia glomerulonephritis
  • Drug of choice for HSP is steroids

questions.text: Which of the following is not found in men2b syndrome?
questions.solution:
MEN 1 - pituitary adenoma, parathyroid adenoma, entero pancreatic tumor

MEN2A - medullary Ca thyroid, Pheochromocytoma, Parathyroid adenoma

MEN1B - MTC Pheochromocytoma, mucosal neuroma, marfanoid habitus, medullated corneal nerve fibres, megacolon

MEN4 - Parathyroid adenoma, pituitary adenoma, Reproductive organ tumors(Testicular ca, Neuroendocrine cervical ca) Adrenal and renal tumor, Gene identified CDKN1B

questions.text: An obese woman came to OPD with dark patches on neck. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Obesity with dark patches in the neck(Acanthosis nigricans) is seen in metabolic syndrome.

Acanthosis nigricans typically occurs in people who are obese or have diabetes.

It can be described as dark, velvety patches of skin often appear in the armpits, groin, and neck.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever and severe calf pain. On examination conjunctival effusion is seen with petechial eruption and thrombocytopenia. The abdomen shows tender hepatomegaly and icterus. KFT is normal and urine microscopic examination shows haematuria. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Fever with hepato renal dysfunction hemorrhage, Calf tenderness is typical of leptospirosis.

It is also called as weil's disease caused by a bacteria called leptospira.

Symptoms of leptospirosis include high fever, red eyes, headache, muscle aches, abdominal pain.

Drug of choice is doxycycline.

questions.text: A 40 year old male presents with fever, dry cough and dyspnea on exertion for the past 3 months. Patient has a past history of bilateral LMN facial palsy and recurrent uveitis. Chest X-ray shows bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Bilateral LMN facial palsy and recurrent uveitis along with x-ray, showing bilateral higher lymphadenopathy suggestive towards sarcoidosis.

This history does not fit in any other option

questions.text: 62 year old male presented with rigidity, bradykinesia and mask like facies. Which of the following drugs can be used as a part of treatment?
questions.solution:
The question describes the typical history of parkinsonism.

Drugs used in treatment of Parkinson's disease:

  • Dopamine precursor Levodopa
  • MAO-B inhibitors Selegiline, Rasagiline, Safinamide
  • COMT inhibitor Entacapone
  • NMDA receptor antagonist Amantadine
  • Dopamine agonist - Ropinirole, Pramipexole Apomorphine
  • Anticholinergics Trihexyphenidyl
  • A2A receptor antagonist. Istradefylline

questions.text: 50 year old male presented with dragging abdominal pain and fatigue for the past 4 months. On examination, there was massive splenomegaly. Blood investigations showed leukocytosis with increased myelocytes, metamyelocytes and mature neutrophils. What is the translocation?
questions.solution:
The given history along with blood investigations suggest patient has CML

CML has translocation of 9, 22 with the fusion of BCR ABL gene.

Blood picture of CML shows a college girl appearance.

  1. 15,17 translocation is seen in AML M3.
  2. 8,14 translocation is seen in Burkitt lymphoma.
  3. 14,18 translocation seen in follicular carcinoma

questions.text: All the following drugs may cause pleural effusion except?
questions.solution:
Drug-induced pleural disease

  1. Nitrofurantoin
  2. Dantrolene
  3. Methysergide
  4. Bromocriptine
  5. Procarbazine
  6. Amiodarone
  7. Dasatinib

questions.text: 30 year old male presents with fever, malaise and right upper quadrant pain. Evaluation showed HBsAg +ve, anti HBsAg negative, IgM anti HBc Ag + ve, anti HCV negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
8 year old child presents with chronic diarrhea, steatorrhea and weight loss. Intestinal biopsy showed loss of villi and crypt hyperplasia. He is HLA DQ2 positive. What should be the dietary advice?
questions.solution: The given history of chronic diarrhoea, weight loss, along with biopsy, suggesting loss of Villi and crypt hyperplasia with HLA, DQ, two and eight positive all points towards Celiac disease, which is gluten sensitive.

questions.text: A female is brought to the emergency department Swith deliberate self harm taking 20 tablets of paracetamol. Which of the following can be used in the management of the patient?
questions.solution:
Questions suggest paracetamol toxicity. Drug of choice for PCM toxicity is N acetyl cysteine.

Naloxon is the drug of choice for opioid toxicity.

Glucagon is given to treat hypoglycemia.

Flumazenil is the drug of choice for benzodiazepines.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of C.L.D. with ascites presents with abdominal pain and tenderness. Ascitic tap shows presence of 600pmn cells/cu.mm. Which of the following is the likely etiology?
questions.solution:
Abdominal pain and tenderness in a C.L.D. patient with ascites suggests SBP, if the ascitic fluid analysis shows PMNC>250/mm3.

  • SBP is also seen in ascites due to nephrotic syndrome, heart failure, acute hepatitis. Rare in malignant ascites.
  • SBP is characterized by the culture of a single organism.
  • SBP is due to enteric pathogens - E coli, Klebsiella, Streptococcus, Enterococci.

TB ascites will have ascitic fluid lymphocytosis. AFB smear is 0.3% positive. In patients without cirrhosis an elevated ADA has > 90% sensitivity.

Chylous ascites are seen with milky ascitic fluid with TG>200 mg/dl. It is due to lymphatic disruption occurring with trauma, cirrhosis, tumor, TB or certain congenital abnormalities.

Black fluid-Pancreatic necrosis or metastatic melanoma

Presence of multiple pathogens in ascitic fluid without PMN elevation suggests bowel perforation with paracentesis needle.
